entry.title: Afghanistan: Opium cultivation drops sharply, but regional trafficking rises
entry.summary: Opium poppy cultivation in Afghanistan has fallen by 20 per cent compared to last year, continuing a dramatic decline since the introduction of a nationwide ban under the Taliban in 2022 â€“ but synthetic drugs and shifting trafficking routes are posing new challenges.

entry.title: The science of why your body resists weight loss
entry.summary:
Our bodies evolved to survive famine, not dieting. Researchers are decoding how metabolism, hunger, and hormones conspire to make keeping weight off so difficult. Research shows the battle to keep weight off isnâ€™t about willpowerâ€”itâ€™s biology. Hereâ€™s how scientists say we can work with our bodies, not against them.
Losing weight is hard. More than half of Americans want to do so, but keeping it off is even harder. Research shows that 80 to 95 percent of people who lose weight regain it within three to five years, according to data from the National Institutes of Health and the Obesity Society.
Scientists say thatâ€™s not a failure of willpower. Hormones, genetics, and even evolution push the body to fight backâ€”driving hunger up, slowing metabolism, and urging the pounds to returâ€¦

entry.title: How Sicily has celebrated its diversity through the centuries
entry.summary:
Sicily is said to be the 'Gates of Europe', where stories of immigration shape the island's history and present. A journey across Sicily reveals the essence of an island shaped by outsiders, where successive waves of immigration over the centuries have created a unique cultural identity.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Dust swirls in a quiet kasbah, stirred by the sirocco â€” the desert wind that carries soft Saharan sand across the Mediterranean Sea, its red grains falling in a blood rain. In the fortified central quarter, a shutter is brightly painted with the hamsa, the symbol of an open palm inset with a blue iris, believed across North Africa to deter the evil eye. AÂ woman in a slate-grey headscarf and abaya robe-dress sweeps past, offerinâ€¦

entry.title: How to see the northern lights in Alaska
entry.summary:
Travelers who want to experience the Northern Lights firsthand should consider visiting Alaska, such as Arctic Hive, a remote wilderness retreat center in the Brooks Range. Americaâ€™s northernmost state is the perfect front-row seat to the aurora borealisâ€”and this winter will be an extra special time to see it.
Much of Americaâ€™s northernmost state,Â Alaska, lies in the auroral oval, a donut-shaped region of light activity above Earthâ€™s geomagnetic North and South Poles. The green and violet ribbons delight travelers during any Alaska aurora seasonâ€”but this winter could be extra special. Thatâ€™s because the sun,Â which triggers the spectacle, is in its roughly 11-year peak of activity.
â€œYou can have aurora every single night in some capacity,â€ saysÂ Vince Ledvina, a professional aurâ€¦

entry.title: The Grand Ole Opry enters its next century
entry.summary:
Country singers on stage at the Grand Ole Opry celebrating the show's 100th anniversary. Opry staple Vince Gill sits on the left playing his guitar. â€œPeople want to paint [the Opry] as a closed shop," Gill told National Geographic, "but itâ€™s not the conservative flagship itâ€™s known to be.â€ We went behind the scenes at the world's oldest radio show to understand how it endured 100 yearsâ€”and why it might last 100 more.
Hours before the Grand Ole Opry launched its Holy Saturday broadcast earlier this year, dozens of country music fans had already gathered in the pollen-covered courtyard outside. A high-school orchestra played nearby as families, double dates, exhausted tourists, cowgirl-booted bachelorette parties, the full Nashville ecosystem, all waited on stone benches as the oldesâ€¦

entry.title: Here are 6 amazing ancient tattoosâ€”and the stories behind them
entry.summary:
This mummy, held at the Museo Maria Reiche in Nazca, Peru, likely belonged to a male who lived 500 to 750 years ago in the lower Nazca River Valley and who may have played an important role in agriculture and fertility rites. As researchers discover overlooked tattoos on mummies from around the world, it's prompting new insights about some of the world's oldest ink.
It took well over a century for archaeologists to start taking ancient tattoos seriously, with old colonialist attitudes and more contemporary stigmas steering scholars away. Whatâ€™s more, ancient tattoos can be difficult to study: Tattooing tools are tricky to identify in the archaeological record, and only rarely is ink well enough preserved on mummies to be visible with the naked eye.
But these days, new attitudeâ€¦

entry.title: Methodology
entry.summary: About Pew Research Centerâ€™s Spring 2025 Global Attitudes Survey Results for the survey are based on a mix of telephone, face-to-face and online interviews conducted under the direction of Gallup, Langer Research Associates and Social Research Centre. The results are based on national samples, unless otherwise noted. Read more about our international survey methodology and [â€¦] The post Methodology appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Acknowledgments
entry.summary: This report is a collaborative effort based on the input and analysis of the following individuals. Moira Fagan, Research AssociateKirsten Lesage, Research AssociateWilliam Miner, Research AnalystAndrew Prozorovsky, Research Assistant Julia Armeli, Research AssistantDorene Asare-Marfo, Senior Panel ManagerPeter Bell, Associate Director, Design and ProductionJanakee Chavda, Associate Digital ProducerLaura Clancy, Research AnalystJonathan Evans, Senior ResearcherJanell Fetterolf, Senior [â€¦] The post Acknowledgments appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Appendix: Political categorization
entry.summary: For this analysis, we grouped people into two political categories: those who support the governing political party (or parties) in their country, and those who do not. These categories were coded based on the party or parties in power at the time the survey was fielded and on respondentsâ€™ answers to a question asking which [â€¦] The post Appendix: Political categorization appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 2. Dealing with climate change
entry.summary: Majorities in nine middle income countries are willing to make lifestyle changes to curb the effects of climate change â€“ younger adults especially so. The post 2. Dealing with climate change appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 1. Impact of climate change
entry.summary: A 74% median across nine middle-income countries say global climate change is affecting their area, with droughts or water shortages a top concern. The post 1. Impact of climate change appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: People in Middle-Income Countries Say Climate Change Is Affecting Their Community
entry.summary: Large majorities in nine middle-income countries say global climate change is affecting their community. About half or more in Argentina, Brazil and Mexico see a great deal of impact. The post People in Middle-Income Countries Say Climate Change Is Affecting Their Community appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: With new rules for disability insurance, states that will be affected the most
entry.summary: The administration aims to make it harder to claim disability insurance. Eli Hager,â€¦ Tags: health, insurance, ProPublica

entry.title: Doha: World Summitâ€™s second day highlights urgency of investing in people and peace
entry.summary: As the Second World Summit for Social Development continued in Doha on Wednesday, governments warned that global progress risks stalling unless social protection, equality and peace are prioritised â€“ and backed with political and financial commitment.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Doha Social Summit: Businesses, civil society walk side by side for fairer futures
entry.summary: Civil society networks and private sector leaders crossed paths in the buzzing corridors of the Qatar National Convention Centre, a reminder that social development is not just debated in meetings rooms â€“ it touches jobs, families and futures.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Sudan war and political uncertainty block progress on Abyei peace talks
entry.summary: The UN is ready to support Sudan and South Sudan in resuming talks on the disputed Abyei border region, the Security Council heard on Wednesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Sudan crisis: UN agencies race to aid civilians as violence engulfs El Fasher
entry.summary: UN agencies are stepping up relief operations to help civilians fleeing the escalating violence in Sudanâ€™s North Darfur state, where fighting has triggered widespread abuses and mass displacement, Deputy UN Spokesperson Farhan Haq told reporters in New York on Wednesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Hurricane Melissa: UN launches $74 million response for 2.2 million in Cuba
entry.summary: Around 2.2 million Cubans remain in dire need of assistance across the eastern provinces of Granma, Santiago de Cuba, Holguin, and Guantanamo as the after effects of Hurricane Mellisa continue, UN aid workers said on Wednesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: World News in Brief: Famine alert for South Sudan, tsunami readiness, peacekeepers flag activity along Lebanon â€˜blue lineâ€™
entry.summary: To South Sudan, where aid teams warn that an already severe food and nutrition crisis could get worse without urgent humanitarian relief.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Not just dreams, but rights: Social justice in focus at Doha summit
entry.summary: The push to put social justice at the heart of global policymaking took centre stage at the Second World Summit for Social Development on Wednesday, as leaders gathered for a high-level forum to drive coordinated action in delivering the newly adopted Doha Political Declaration.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Catch-up immunization campaign â€˜a lifelineâ€™ for Gazaâ€™s children
entry.summary: A campaign for routine immunization, nutrition, and growth monitoring will be launched in the Gaza Strip this week with the goal of reaching 44,000 children cut off from essential life-saving services due to the devastating conflict.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Mind over machine: UN urges ethical guardrails for brain tech revolution
entry.summary: As wearable devices begin to tap into our mental states, UN experts warn that without ethical safeguards, the right to freedom of thought could be the latest casualty of unchecked innovation.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Worldâ€™s forests at serious risk from warming planet, fires and pests: UNECE
entry.summary: Decades of progress in protecting the planetâ€™s carbon dioxide-busting forests are at risk as the climate crisis continues to accelerate, UN forestry experts said on Wednesday.

entry.title: Meet Antarctica's penguins with an ornithologist
entry.summary:
In Antarctica, the weather can flip faster than almost anywhere on Earth â€” itâ€™s not unusual for skies to be clear one minute and a blizzard to blow in the next. Step out of a helicopter onto a never-before-seen island in Antarcticaâ€™s distant south during this expert-led tour around endless icebergs, frozen cliffs and mercurial glaciers.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
For the explorer Ernest Shackleton, it was the glory of reaching the South Pole that brought him to Antarctica. For polar polymath Fabrice Genevois, it was something far less dangerous: penguins.
And so, 150 miles south of the Antarctic Circle, as we land on the shore of Red Rock Ridge, Fabrice announces itâ€™s time to get obsessed with the flightless birds ourselves. â€œKeep qâ€¦

entry.title: How Men and Women Spend Their Days
entry.summary: Women and men tend to spend their days differently in the United States. Varying responsibilities and priorities will do that. Tags: time use

entry.title: Why are Alaskaâ€™s rivers turning bright orange?
entry.summary:
Tukpahlearick Creek is one of many rivers and creeks in remote Alaska that has recently turned a bright orange. The dramatic shift is a warning signâ€”and scientists say the changes that aren't yet visible to the naked eye are just as troubling.
In the summer of 2019, ecologist Patrick Sullivan and a Super Cub plane pilot navigated over the narrow valleys of the Brooks Range in northern Alaska, winding toward the remote headwaters of the Salmon River. Sullivan was studying the slow advance of trees into what had been tundra, a sign of the rapidly changing climate, but soon discovered something far more surprising.
Sullivan was expecting a clear, cold river artery with blue-green pools, and had even brought his fishing rod. So he was shocked to see turbid water and banks stainedâ€¦

entry.title: I set out to see the Serengeti's Great Migrationâ€”here's what happened
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
â€œItâ€™s not a mathematical calculation,â€ says my seasoned guide Allan Dawson, his brow furrowing as he smooths out a giant battered map of migration patterns over the dinner table. A bite-sized pakora in one hand, he points with the other to where we are in the far northwestern corner of Tanzania, just below the border with Kenyaâ€™s Maasai Mara. And then his finger moves south, down below the Mara River â€” famed for its dramatic animal river crossings â€” and down further still, to the central Serengeti. Itâ€™s here, he says, that the herds of wildebeest and zebras have stopped.
Itâ€™s the first day of a trip to witness the Great Migration, in which the herds make their annual pilgrimage north across the 5,791sq-mile Serengeâ€¦

entry.title: This Scottish trail is the best way to explore the Highlands
entry.summary:
The lone Highlander atop the Glenfinnan Monument, situated on the edge of Loch Shiel, is just one of many sites that hikers, runners, and walkers may encounter along the West Highlands Way in Scotland. Following old military roads through pine forests and barren moorland, hikers trace centuries of lore while experiencing a taste of local life.
TheÂ West Highland Way in Scotland stretches 96 miles across the Highlands from Milngavie to Fort William. Considered by many to be a moderate-to-difficult trail due to steep ascents and occasionally technical terrain, roughly 45,000 hikers attempt to complete the trail each year, with about the same number tackling individual stages or sections. As the countryâ€™s first and most popular waymarked trail, it has become a wildly important cornerstâ€¦

entry.title: The best ways to measure your fitness, according to science
entry.summary:
A woman folds into a standing forward bend, or uttanasana. Flexibility and joint mobilityâ€”key elements of this poseâ€”are among the most overlooked indicators of physical health. VO2 max? Mile time? Experts break down the most common health metrics and reveal which ones actually best reflect on your fitness at mid-life.
We count steps, track miles, and close our rings. Athletic metrics have infiltrated everything from viral #FitTok videos to biometric-tracking devices.
But when our devices remind us we havenâ€™t hit our daily goal, experts say it might be time to question what those numbers really mean.Â
â€œIt's not so simple to just say, if you can do 20 push-ups and if you can run a 10 minute mile, you're good,â€ says Mathias Sorensen, an exercise physiologist at the UCSF Humâ€¦

entry.title: Is there really an Ozempic baby boom?
entry.summary:
Developed for diabetes, GLP-1 drugs have become popular for weight loss. Researchers are investigating how they may influence fertility and pregnancy. These medications may be influencing fertility in ways scientists are only beginning to understand.
When the GLP-1 medications were first approved for weight loss, â€œI got pregnant on Ozempicâ€ headlines quickly followed. People spoke about sudden unintended pregnancy, and â€œOzempic babiesâ€ entered the lexicon.
Could a medication meant to combat diabetes and shrink waistlines also boost fertility? For some, especially people struggling with infertility, these accounts sparked hope. For others, they raised new fears: Could these blockbuster drugs make birth control less effective?
The real story is not so simple. While anecdoteâ€¦

entry.title: Doha: World Summit opens with pledge to speed social progress
entry.summary: The Second World Summit for Social Development opened in Doha on Tuesday with the adoption of the Doha Political Declaration â€“ a consensus pledge to accelerate action on poverty eradication, decent work and social inclusion, and to put the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) back on track.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Doha Social Summit: Path to fairer societies begins in the classroom
entry.summary: Education took centre stage on the opening day of the Second World Summit for Social Development in Doha, where leaders, educators and youth advocates underscored that learning is the foundation of inclusive and resilient societies.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: World News in Brief: Settler attacks in the West Bank, Madagascar hunger crisis, obesity in Europe
entry.summary: The UN humanitarian relief chief, Tom Fletcher, has sounded the alarmÂ over rising violence in the occupied West Bank, where attacks by Israeli settlers on Palestinians and their property continue to escalate.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Half of Jamaicaâ€™s population reeling from Hurricane Melissa
entry.summary: More than 1.5 million Jamaicans have been impacted by the devastation resulting from Hurricane Melissa, many losing their homes and livelihoods.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Potential Gaza stabilization force must have Security Council approval: Guterres
entry.summary: Any transition in Gaza must uphold unity with the West Bank and a two-State solution between Israelis and Palestinians, the UN Secretary-General said in Doha on Tuesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Famine declared in two Sudanese cities cut off by war, fragile gains elsewhere
entry.summary: New analysis of hunger and malnutrition in war-torn Sudan has revealed sharp contrasts along conflict lines, three UN agencies reported on Tuesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Syriaâ€™s future under threat from acute funding shortages
entry.summary: Hopes for a peaceful future in post-war Syria are at risk as funding for basic services dries up, the World Health Organization (WHO) said on Tuesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: New climate pledges do little to correct global warming projection, UN warns
entry.summary: Available new climate pledges by governments have only slightly lowered global temperature rise over the course of this century, leaving the world on the path to a serious escalation of climate risks and damages.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Gaza: Aid teams race to push back hunger; one million food parcels delivered
entry.summary: Food is slowly returning to the shelves in Gaza but supplies are still desperately inadequate, UN humanitarians said on Tuesday, as they issued fresh calls for wider access and continued financial support.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: World leaders adopt Doha declaration to boost efforts on social development
entry.summary: Against a backdrop of escalating geopolitical tension and widening social divides, global leaders at the Second World Summit for Social Development on Tuesday adopted the Doha Political Declaration, signalling renewed resolve to advance justice and inclusion worldwide.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Around 224 million women still donâ€™t access family planning
entry.summary: Since 1990, the number of people using modern contraception methods has doubled globally but despite this, nearly 224 million women in mainly developing regions still do not use safe and effective family planning methods, according to the UN sexual and reproductive health agency, UNFPA

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: LIVE from Doha: Second World Summit for Social Development
entry.summary: Leaders, policymakers and civil society representatives have gathered in Doha for the Second World Summit for Social Development, with the aim of renewing global commitments to inclusion, dignity and social justice. UN News is on the ground, bringing you live updates, key highlights and human stories from inside the conference halls and beyond. Follow this page for rolling coverage throughout the Summit. App users can follow the coverage here.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Why India has one of the world's most creative restaurant scenes
entry.summary:
Today, fine dining in India aims to highlight the diversity of cuisine across its 28 states. Across the country, inventive fine-dining restaurants are flowering like garlands in temples â€” from the Himalayan foothills down to Chennaiâ€™s shores.
This article was produced byÂ National Geographic TravellerÂ (UK).
A new generation of Indian chefs is tapping into the countryâ€™s diverse culinary traditions and pushing their boundaries, crafting innovative tasting menus and dishes such as reimagined biryani and chilli-salted plum lollipops. But just a decade ago, fine-dining restaurants in India were surprisingly few and far between, especially outside key metropolitan hubs. The arrival of Delhiâ€™s Indian Accent and its six-course tasting menu in 2009 was significant, but it didn't sparkâ€¦

entry.title: Acknowledgements
entry.summary: This data essay was written by Ziyao Tian, research associate, Mark Hugo Lopez, director of race and ethnicity research, Jeffrey Passel, senior demographer, and Jens Manuel Krogstad, former senior writer/editor. The essay and the accompanying digital features were produced by Sara Atske, digital producer. Nick Zanetti, associate engineer, built the essayâ€™s interactivity. John Carlo Mandapat, [â€¦] The post Acknowledgements appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Methodology
entry.summary: The American Trends Panel survey methodology Overview Data in this report comes from Wave 174 of the American Trends Panel (ATP), Pew Research Centerâ€™s nationally representative panel of randomly selected U.S. adults. The survey was conducted from June 16 to June 29, 2025. A total of 6,871 panelists responded out of 12,032 who were sampled, [â€¦] The post Methodology appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Counting Race: How the Census Measures Identity and What Americans Think About It
entry.summary: How the U.S. government measures race has changed substantially since censuses began in 1790. Today, Americans differ on whether the government should ask about race. The post Counting Race: How the Census Measures Identity and What Americans Think About It appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: The first woman to climb Mount Fuji did it in secret
entry.summary:
An illustration of Mount Fuji in the morning. Women were banned from climbing the mountain until 1872. In 1832, Tatsu Takayama made a defiant climb up to the top of Mount Fuji dressed as a man. This is the story of her historic journey.
The grave of Tatsu Takayama is unassuming and plain. Sheâ€™s buried within SaishÅ-ji Temple, in a quiet corner of western Tokyo, under a stone pillar nearly indistinguishable from the others around it.
And yet the bones there carry with them the remarkable spirit of a woman whose reverence for the mountainsâ€”and courage to honor themâ€”has long outlasted her story.
In 1832, Takayama became the first woman to summit Mount Fujiâ€”which, at the time, was forbidden for women to climb. In defiance of common law and religious custom, she went anyway, dâ€¦

entry.title: Test driving the next generation of moon rovers
entry.summary:
Before me is an expansive, arid landscapeâ€”a realm of valleys, chasms, and crevasses, of steep cliffs and dusty soil, framed by distant mountains. It might as well be on the moon itself, save for the scattered scrub, azure sky, and occasional rattlesnake.Â Â
Not too far back, on the dirt road, you can spot a signpost: LUNAR VEHICLE TEST SITE. This is no ordinary patch of desert. â€œI get to come out here and drive space trucks,â€ says Justin Cyrus, the CEO of Lunar Outpost, with a grin, surveying his playground.Â
A prototype of a vehicle he hopes to send to the actual moon stands nearby, its platinum-hued paint gleaming in the sun. Itâ€™s adorned with top-mounted solar panels, wide side radiators to reemit that scorching dayside lunar heat away from the vehicle, flat work benches, aâ€¦

entry.title: Why the Vietnam War dragged on for decades
entry.summary: Millions of casualties. Years of bloody attrition warfare. When Vietnamese communists toppled French colonial rule in 1954 despite massive U.S. military aid, the Geneva Accords temporarily divided Vietnam into two zones until free elections could be held in 1956 to unify the country. However, those elections never happened. Within a few years, terrorism and firefights began. The ensuing civil war would last for two decades. But why? â€œIt was not because [policymakers] were greatly confident that fighting on would lead to victory,â€ says Christian G. Appy, professor of history at the University of Massachusetts Amherst and the author of three books about the Vietnam War. Instead, the lengthy war hinged on factors like ideology, public sentiment, and the agendas of powerful individualsâ€”with deâ€¦

entry.title: Nearly 6 million people in the Caribbean impacted by Hurricane Melissa
entry.summary: Some six million people have been affected by the category five hurricane which swept across the Caribbean last week, prompting UN agencies to scale up relief operations to safeguard livelihoods and reduce further losses.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: World News in Brief: Self-sufficiency call for healthcare funding, Australia treaty with Indigenous Peoples, Haiti women at risk
entry.summary: The UN World Health Organization (WHO) issued new guidance on Monday to help poorer nations cope with severe global funding cuts for essential medical services worldwide.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: In a quiet community on Dohaâ€™s edge, Gazaâ€™s wounded and orphaned learn to heal
entry.summary: In the late afternoon light, about 20 kilometres from Doha, the Al-Thumama complex looks like any quiet residential neighbourhood: paved pathways, rows of apartment blocks, the hum of air-conditioning carrying through the warm desert air.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Gaza: Food access improves in the south but food convoys fail to reach north directly
entry.summary: In its latest update from Gaza, the UN aid coordination office, OCHA, said that access to food improved in early October, especially in southern governorates.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Surviving the next pandemic could depend on where you live
entry.summary: A new global report warns that inequality is increasing the worldâ€™s vulnerability to pandemics, making them more deadly, more costly and longer lasting â€“ and where you live, could determine how badly impacted you are.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Famine tightens grip on Sudan, with civilians trapped and aid blocked
entry.summary: Sudanâ€™s hunger crisis has deepened further, with new UN-backed analysis confirming that famine is underway in parts of Darfur and Kordofan, where fighting and sieges have cut off entire communities from food and aid.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Fresh push to fight toxic mercury pollution underway
entry.summary: Representatives from countries around the world are working together to reduce mercury pollution and protect people and the planet, at a major international meeting which got underway on Monday in Geneva, Switzerland.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: FAO warns of â€˜silent crisisâ€™ as land degradation threatens billions
entry.summary: Roughly 1.7 billion people are living in areas where crop yields are failing due to human-induced land degradation â€“ â€œa pervasive and silent crisis that is undermining agricultural productivity and threatening ecosystem health worldwide.â€

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN agencies on hand as deadly new quake hits northern Afghanistan
entry.summary: UN teams rushed to northern Afghanistan on Monday after a powerful 6.3 magnitude earthquake struck overnight, just two months after a massive quake devastated the east of the country. Details are still emerging from the latest emergency where initial reports indicate at least 20 people have been killed and hundreds injured.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: As global crises deepen, leaders in Doha urge shift from promises to action
entry.summary: As global challenges deepen, governments, civil society and international partners convened in Doha on Monday to highlight concrete solutions to advance social development and confront some of todayâ€™s most urgent crises â€“ from widening hunger and poverty to growing inequality and climate-driven instability.

entry.title: â€˜To Do Truly Great Investigations, You Need to Uncover the Hidden Informationâ€™: Veteran Swedish Journalist on Using Large Datasets
entry.summary: Data editor Helena Bengtsson once asked the national statistics agency to cross-match a teachers database with another featuring court convictions. The findings led to a change in Swedish law.

entry.title: Tracing an ancient MÄori jade trade route in New Zealand
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Te Rua Mason believes finding pounamu is much like finding love. Despite the spitting rain and biting wind, Te Rua, his son Henare and I are picking our way along the pebbled mouth of the Arahura River outside Hokitika township. The steel-grey Tasman Sea crashes and foams against the shore nearby, hurling salty spray into the air. Sky-wheeling seagulls bicker and caw.
The weather might be dreary but Te Rua, my guide and founder of Te Rua and Sons Pounamu Trail tours, says itâ€™s a good day to search for pounamu, a type of jade found exclusively on the west coast of New Zealandâ€™s South Island. Too much sunlight can wash everything in an indiscernible glare â€” rain helps the stoneâ€™s natural green stand out among the limâ€¦

entry.title: Take part in a master-led healing retreat in the Maldives
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
My body is melting into a puddle of gold. In reality, Iâ€™m lying on the floor in a timber-clad room suspended over a sparkling Indian Ocean lagoon. Both sound far-fetched, but Iâ€™m at a master-led healing retreat in the Maldives, and scenarios like this have become my new normal.
Iâ€™ve travelled to The Ritz-Carlton Maldives, Fari Islands to spend four days with Susy Markoe Schieffelin, an LA-based sound healer, kundalini yoga teacher and reiki master, whoâ€™s in residence at the hotel as part of its Masters of Crafts programme.

entry.title: Is this the best way to see the Seychelles?
entry.summary:
This article was produced byÂ National Geographic TravellerÂ (UK).
Perfect palms arcing over white, fine-grain sand; smooth, sparkling granite boulders rising along the rainforest-clad coastline; and crystalline waters as far as the eye can see â€” Seychelles rightly lives up to its name as one of the worldâ€™s most idyllic escapes. An archipelago made up of 115 islands, the Indian Ocean nation located off the eastern coast of Africa has long lured travellers thanks to its superlative natural beauty and enticing mix of Creole, French and English heritage.
Uninhabited until 1770, when the French established a settlement here, and independent since 1976, Seychelles is one of the youngest nations in Africa â€” but, thanks to a small population and a focus on luxury tourism and fishing, itâ€™â€¦

entry.title: Paganism is on the riseâ€”hereâ€™s where to discover its traditions
entry.summary:
The Ivana Kupala festival, in Kyiv, Ukraine, is part of an ancient pagan tradition believed to cleanse sins and bring good health. TikTokâ€”specifically #witchtokâ€”is fueling interest in paganism. Hereâ€™s how to immerse yourself in full moon rituals, spellcasting, and more.
Interest in Paganism and its ritualsâ€”crystals and tarot cards, astrology, and herbal magicâ€”has brought pagan religion from the fringes back to the center of pop culture, or at least to the top of your TikTok feed.
In ancient times, Celts traveled windy moors to worship the horned god, Cernunnos. Egyptians crossed deserts to invoke the protection of Isis and Osiris. Druids journeyed to a forest clearing to perform rituals under the moon. But over time, such gods and goddesses faded into myth; the rituals of thisâ€¦

entry.title: Who were the Cathars?
entry.summary:
Early 13th-century Europe saw a rise in dissident Christian communities, including the Cathars and the Waldenses, in several regions of Europe. The dissident movements questioned central elements of Catholic doctrine: the validity of the sacraments and the Churchâ€™s message on salvation of the soul. They believed the Church and its members had moved away from the Christian ideal and they demanded a return to evangelical poverty. Before the Inquisition, the Catholic Church addressed doctrinal dissent by organizing public debates with the dissenters in an attempt to bring them back to the â€œtrue faith.â€
Diego de Acebes, bishop of the Castilian diocese of Burgode Osma, who saw firsthand how Catharism was taking hold, warned the Catholic prelates of southern France about the need to change â€¦

entry.title: To experience the real D.C., visit these 7 neighborhoods
entry.summary:
Virginia Ali and her husband Ben Ali openedÂ Benâ€™s Chili BowlÂ in Washington, D.C.â€™s U Street neighborhood in 1958 when she was 24. The diner serving homemade chili and its signature half-smokes (half pork, half beef sausages) became a fixture on Black Broadway, the epicenter of Black society and the Civil Rights Movement in the nationâ€™s capital from the 1920s through the 1950s. â€œWhen we opened Benâ€™s, we wanted it to be a welcoming place for everybody, and it became a gathering place,â€ says Ali, 92.Â
Just two miles away from the Districtâ€™s iconic Washington Monument on the National Mall, Benâ€™s Chili Bowl is an attraction of its ownâ€”a local neighborhood gem and a D.C. time capsule with stories of presidents and historical figures, too. Benâ€™s is just one of the many restaurants, shops, thâ€¦

entry.title: Novemberâ€™s supermoon will be the biggest and brightest of 2025
entry.summary:
A supermoon lights up Longquan Mountain in Chengdu, China, on August 19, 2024. This Novemberâ€™s full moon will appear even closer to Earth, glowing larger and brighter in the autumn sky. The glow of the moon will even cast faint shadows on the ground, a rare effect visible only during the most intense supermoons. Hereâ€™s the best time to see and photograph it.
On November 4, the moon will put on its brightest and largest show of the year. Itâ€™s the second in a series of three consecutive supermoons closing out 2025.
Sometimes called the â€œbeaver moon,â€ this full moonâ€™s nameâ€”traditionally used by various Indigenous peoples of North Americaâ€”marks the season when beavers build their winter lodges and when trappers once set out before rivers froze over.
The size difference might â€¦

entry.title: What's missing at the new Grand Egyptian Museum?
entry.summary:
You won't find the western Luxor Obelisk at the Grand Egyptian Museumâ€”Egypt's highly anticipated new museum filled with treasures of antiquity. The obelisk was gifted from Egypt to France, where it remains on the Place de la Concorde, Paris. The hotly anticipated new museum boasts some of the greatest treasures of antiquity. But there are some notable exceptions.
After more than two decades and with plenty of hiccups along the way, the Grand Egyptian Museumâ€”colloquially, the â€œGEMâ€â€”finally officially opens in Cairo on November 1.
The halls of the museum are filled to the brim with priceless artifacts like the colossus statue of Ramesses II, Khufuâ€™s ancient royal boats, and 5,000 treasures from Tutankhamunâ€™s tombâ€”which will be displayed together for the first time since the tombâ€¦

entry.title: What caused Strasbourgâ€™s dancing plague of 1518?
entry.summary:
Around 400 people danced for days without rest in Strasbourg, Alsace during the dancing plague of 1518. Over the course of about one month, some of those affected died of heart attack, stroke, or exhaustion. Mass hysteria? Ergot poisoning? Or just despair? Hereâ€™s why what started as one womanâ€™s dance spiraled into one of historyâ€™s strangest outbreaks.
TheÂ Black DeathÂ rightfully stands top of mind among historic plagues. Yet there was an odder malady that also swept across medieval and Renaissance Europe: the dancing plague, also known as choreomania.
It saw large groups of people dancing for prolonged periods in an erratic, frenzied manner, seemingly unable to control their movements or stop moving to the point of collapse, with some dying as a result. Groups ballooned into thâ€¦

entry.title: What if aliens existâ€”but theyâ€™re just hiding from us?
entry.summary:
Could there be a technologically advanced extraterrestrial society hiding in NGC 604, a star-forming region of the Triangulum Galaxy captured here by the James Webb Space Telescope? Astronomers have long wondered why we haven't yet encountered alien civilizations even though humanity is young and our universe is ancientâ€”a conundrum known as the Fermi Paradox. The Dark Forest theory is just one explanation for our lack of encounters with extraterrestrial intelligence.
The Dark Forest theory is one proposed solution to the famed Fermi Paradox, which has bewitched astronomers for more than half a century. To put it concisely, the paradox asks if the cosmos is nearly 14 billion years old, then where are all the interstellar societies? Why havenâ€™t they popped over to say hello? Myriad sâ€¦

entry.title: A British tradition you canâ€™t missâ€”16 of the UKâ€™s best Sunday roasts
entry.summary:
Chef Luke Payne's Sunday menu at The Pack Horse is popular with walkers, day-trippers and locals within this Peak District hotspot. In the UK the roast dinner is often the highlight of Sunday, especially when itâ€™s served up in a cosy pub, with local ingredients and a touch of contemporary flair.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK)
In Britain, the Sunday roast is sacrosanct. Gathering together around a beautifully cooked joint of meat, with lashings of gravy, vegetables and billowing Yorkshire puddings, is, for many, the weekendâ€™s social highlight. And where better to do to this than the pub? Not only do you avoid the washing-up but, centuries after the French dubbed Brits les rosbifs, you get to enjoy the roast at its most modern. In recent decadeâ€¦

entry.title: Was Nanotyrannus real?
entry.summary: Nanotyrannus was long thought to be the very prey it's shown attacking in the illustration above, a young Tyrannosaurus rex. New evidence suggests it was a different class of dinosaur.  After decades of fierce debate, researchers say fossils once thought to be juvenile T. rex actually belong to a separate, sleeker species of tyrannosaur. One of paleontologyâ€™s most polarizing problems is a teenage Tyrannosaurus rex with an identity crisis, and two scientists say theyâ€™ve solved it. In 1942, researchers from the Cleveland Museum of Natural History found the skull of a small theropod in Montanaâ€™s Hell Creek Formation. After scientists classified it as the new species Nanotyrannus lancensis in 1988, the skull sparked four decades of fierce debate: Do â€¦

entry.title: Lyon's bouchons offer a masterclass in traditional French cuisine
entry.summary: Les Fines Gueules is a much-loved, traditional bouchon run by JoÃ«l Salzi, who trained under the legendary Lyonnais chef Paul Bocuse. The city's traditional restaurants, known as bouchons, are an essential part of its identity and a must-visit for authentic local cuisine. Here are seven of the best to try This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK). With rustic wooden furnishings, cosy bistro atmospheres and hearty LyonnaiseÂ cuisine, bouchons have become a symbol of the French city once best known for its chef-led fine-dining scene. Found in the cityâ€™s older quarters, notably concentrated in the arty area of La Croix-Rousse and central Presquâ€™Ãle, sandwiched between the RhÃ´ne and SaÃ´ne rivers, bouchons serve typical local cuisine. Expect such classiâ€¦

entry.title: Methodology
entry.summary: The American Trends Panel survey methodology Overview Data in this report comes from Wave 180 of the American Trends Panel (ATP), Pew Research Centerâ€™s nationally representative panel of randomly selected U.S. adults. The survey was conducted from Sept. 22 to 28, 2025. A total of 3,445 panelists responded out of 3,926 who were sampled, for [â€¦] The post Methodology appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.summary: This report is a collaborative effort based on the input and analysis of the following individuals: Research team Jocelyn Kiley, Director, Political ResearchSteven Shepard, Associate Director, Political ResearchHannah Hartig, Senior ResearcherBaxter Oliphant, Senior ResearcherGabe Borelli, Research AssociateAndrew Daniller, Research AssociateAndy Cerda, Research AnalystJoseph Copeland, Research AnalystShanay Gracia, Research Analyst Ted Van Green, Research Analyst Communications [â€¦] The post Acknowledgments appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 4. How well the Republican and Democratic parties represent Americansâ€™ interests
entry.summary: About four-in-ten U.S. adults (42%) say the Republican Party represents the interests of people like them very or somewhat well. A similar share (40%) say this about the Democratic Party. But majorities say the Republican Party (56%) and Democratic Party (58%) do not represent the interests of people like them. Combining these measures: While most [â€¦] The post 4. How well the Republican and Democratic parties represent Americansâ€™ interests appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 3. What Americans want and expect from party leaders
entry.summary: Wide majorities of Americans say it is important that both Republican and Democratic elected officials are knowledgeable and admit when they are wrong. Smaller majorities say it is very important that elected officials in both parties be willing to make compromises with the other party and treat their counterparts with respect. And while most Republicans [â€¦] The post 3. What Americans want and expect from party leaders appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 2. How Americans see the parties on key issues
entry.summary: All in all, Americans donâ€™t see many good ideas from either political party. But when it comes to specific issues, the Republican Party holds advantages on crime and immigration, while the Democratic Party holds advantages on policies related to race, health care, abortion and the environment. In contrast to a few years ago, neither party [â€¦] The post 2. How Americans see the parties on key issues appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 1. How Americans feel about the Republican and Democratic parties
entry.summary: Americans largely have negative feelings toward both political parties, while positive sentiments are far less common. Three-quarters of U.S. adults say the Democratic Party makes them feel frustrated, while a smaller majority (64%) says the same of the Republican Party. Roughly half of Americans also say the Democratic Party (50%) and the Republican Party (49%) [â€¦] The post 1. How Americans feel about the Republican and Democratic parties appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: A Year Ahead of the Midterms, Americansâ€™ Dim Views of Both Parties
entry.summary: Democratsâ€™ frustration with their own party is up sharply, as many say it hasnâ€™t pushed back hard enough against Trump and the GOP. In contrast, 40% of Republicans say they are frustrated with their party. The post A Year Ahead of the Midterms, Americansâ€™ Dim Views of Both Parties appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: America once made daylight saving time permanent. Hereâ€™s what went wrong.
entry.summary:
Horologist Lawrie Taprell adjusts the clock atop the North Sydney Post Office in Australia in 1989. Twice a year, clockkeepers like Taprell fine-tune public timepieces to match daylight saving shiftsâ€”something the U.S. once tried to make permanent. In 1974, the U.S. tried staying on daylight saving time all year. The result was darker mornings and public panic.
Love it or hate it, daylight saving time (DST) is one of the worldâ€™s most persistent experiments in tinkering with the sun. Roughly one-third of countries worldwide still practice it, but not without controversy.
In the United States, the federal government first standardized the twice-yearly clock change in 1966. Today, people in almost all U.S. statesâ€”with the exceptions being Hawaii and most of Arizonaâ€”â€œsprings forwaâ€¦

entry.title: Why York, England, may be the most haunted city in the world
entry.summary:
York reports a large number of ghost sightings, giving it a reputation as being one of the most haunted cities in Europe. From Roman ruins to candlelit alleyways, this walled city invites travelers to explore the chilling stories that linger where history and the supernatural meet.
Walking through the streets of York, England, feels a bit like traveling back in time. In one afternoon, you can walk among Roman ruins, check out the relics of Viking settlements, and stroll cobbled lanes with crooked medieval buildings. History comes alive in its Gothic cathedrals, Norman castle ruins, and cozy medieval pubs still serving up lagers and whiskeys today.
But what brings much of the visitors to Yorkâ€”particularly in the fallâ€”is its large number of ghost sightings, giving it the reputatâ€¦

entry.title: The comeback of Californiaâ€™s gray wolves just took a tragic turn
entry.summary:
For the first time in over a century, California wildlife officials have taken the drastic measure of legally killing four gray wolves after tensions with local ranchers reached a crisis point.
Earlier this month, the California Department of Fish and Wildlife captured and euthanized a breeding pair after months of complaints from ranchers over numerous livestock kills in a remote region of the Sierra Nevada mountain range known as Sierra Valley. The ultimate goal, according to the department, is to completely remove a seven-member pack called Beyem Seyo, one of 10 packs roaming the state. Two other Beyem Seyo wolves were also killed, and the agency plans to capture and relocate the remaining members to a wildlife sanctuary.
This particular pack has killed at least 87 cattle overâ€¦

entry.title: Putting people at the heart of cities, key to improving urban life
entry.summary: The heartbeat of modern urban life is increasingly digital â€“ from traffic sensors and early warning systems, to participatory planning platforms and geospatial data â€“ technology is changing how cities are designed, managed, and experienced.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: â€˜Normalisingâ€™ Taliban rule would betray Afghan women, warns UN expert
entry.summary: Governments moving to restore ties with the Taliban risk legitimising oppression and deepening Afghanistanâ€™s crisis, an independent UN human rights expert cautioned on Thursday, calling for a principled approach that defends the rights of women and girls.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Hurricane Melissa leaves thousands displaced across the Caribbean
entry.summary: Hurricane Melissa has left a trail of devastation after crossing Jamaica, Cuba and the Bahamas, with severe effects also felt in Haiti, the Dominican Republic and parts of Central America, the UN aid coordination office (UNOCHA) reported on Thursday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: World News in Brief: Ukraine energy targeted, nuclear test warning, rights violations in Nicaragua
entry.summary: Russian armed forces conducted another large-scale combined attack across Ukraine in the early hours of Thursday, reportedly targeting critical energy infrastructure, said the UN Human Rights Monitoring Mission for Ukraine.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN Envoy hails Colombiaâ€™s peace process as global model, calls for more funding
entry.summary: The newly appointed Head of the UN Verification Mission in Colombia, Miroslav JenÄa, has praised the countryâ€™s peace process as â€œa global model,â€ while urging greater financial support to strengthen the Missionâ€™s work.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: â€˜Repeated bouts of violenceâ€™ put Syria rebuilding at risk: Independent rights investigator
entry.summary: Incidents of mass killings and torture in post-Assad Syria are tempering early optimism about the transitional governmentâ€™s ability to put an end to entrenched cycles of violence, the head of the UN-mandated independent investigative body on Syria said on Thursday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: â€˜Blood on the sand. Blood on the handsâ€™: UN decries worldâ€™s failure as Sudanâ€™s El Fasher falls
entry.summary: El Fasher has â€œdescended into an even darker hell,â€ senior UN officials warned on Thursday, as the Rapid Support Forces (RSF) militia seized control of the North Darfur capital after a 500-day siege, forcing tens of thousands to flee on foot amid reports of mass executions, rape and starvation.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Security Council LIVE: Ambassadors meet in emergency session on Sudan
entry.summary: Reports of mass atrocities in and around the newly-captured city of El Fasher in Darfur mark a new low in Sudan's brutal civil war and the Security Council is meeting in emergency session on Thursday morning in New York to address the rapidly deteriorating situation. Civilians are facing starvation and mass displacement as the UN continues providing lifesaving aid throughout the country. Hospitals, schools and IDP camps are under attack, with entire neighborhoods have emptied as families flee the RSF militia. Follow our in-depth live coverage; UN News app users can go here.

entry.title: This Colorado town inspired Disneylandâ€™s Main Street
entry.summary:
Fort Collins, Colorado, was part of the inspiration for Disneyland's "Main Street, U.S.A." Walt Disneyâ€™s vision of an idyllic â€œMain Street, U.S.A.â€ found a muse in the brick-lined charm of this community that is still ranked among the best places to live in the U.S.
When Walt Disney commissioned Harper Goff to help design Disneylandâ€™s Main Street, Goff didnâ€™t have to look far for inspiration. He found it in the brick facades and towers of his childhood hometown, Fort Collins, Colorado, with the buildingsâ€™ late Victorian era architectural details making their way into his 1951 sketches for Walt Disney. Goff poured his nostalgia for the simpler days of his childhood into every detail of Disneyland, ensuring that each child who visited could feel the same magic.
Fort Collins stilâ€¦

entry.title: Why America was so obsessed with Victorian â€˜ghost photosâ€™
entry.summary:
In 1862, jewelry engraver and amateur photographer William H. Mumler was developing a self-portrait in his Boston studio when a ghostly image began to surface. Just below his own image in the photo appeared a young woman in a flowing dress, her features blurred by a ghostly halo.
Mumler showed the picture to his friend, possibly as a joke, and mentioned the woman looked like his deceased cousin. Soon it was being passed through Boston society. It didnâ€™t take long for the local Spiritualist community to learn of the miraculous photo. The news was blasted to their followers via fringe religious journals: spirits had finally been captured on film.
In fact, the woman who appeared next to Mumler was likely Hannah Frances Green, who worked nearby as a photographer and spirit mediumâ€¦

entry.title: The science of why some spaces feel hauntedâ€”even when they're not
entry.summary:
Devoid of students and sound, this empty schoolhouse disorients the brainâ€™s internal mapping system, turning familiar architecture into a landscape of uncertainty. Scientists say such environments reveal how light, space, and silence can trick the senses into sensing danger where none exists. From looping hallways to echoing stairwells, eerie architecture taps into ancient survival instinctsâ€”and exposes how our brains map spaces to protect us from harm.
We often think of homes and hotels as safe, predictable spaces. Yet step into a corridor that stretches farther than your eyes can focus, and your pulse quickens before you even know why.
Scientists say these sensations arenâ€™t superstition but the brain misreading its surroundings. Experts reveal how architectureâ€”through walls,â€¦

entry.title: Caught on the RattleCam: unexpected snake behavior
entry.summary:
Two eastern garter snakes are shown. Scientists are finding that snakes exhibit more social behaviors than previously thought. For a long time, scientists didnâ€™t think snakes needed each other. New research proves that wrong. 
Picture an animal that huddles up with others when stressed, babysits its young, hangs out around relatives, and gathers in big groups every year.Â
Did you imagine a rattlesnake?
For a long time, scientists didnâ€™t think snakes could fit this description.
â€œThere were two big myths out there,â€ said Noam Miller,Â who studies animal social cognition at Wilfrid Laurier University. One is that snakes largely just operated on reflex. The other is that snakes donâ€™t gather in general, since people tend to only come across one snake at a time. â€œSo tâ€¦

entry.title: How to become a cowboy for the day in Scottsdale Arizona
entry.summary:
Since being bestowed the nickname the â€˜Westâ€™s most Western townâ€™ in the 1940s, Scottsdale in Arizona has become better known for its high-end resorts, spas and golf courses. But peel back the shiny top-layer of this cactus-studded city and you'll soon discover Western roots that run deep into the surrounding Sonoran Desertâ€™s rocky terrain. The cowboy spirit is evident throughout Old Town Scottsdale, in its lively saloons and Western-wear boutiques, as well as surrounding ranches and museums that showcase Scottsdaleâ€™s pre- and post-frontier past. From exploring sun-drenched landscapes on horseback to learning to triple-step in a Stetson, hereâ€™s how to embrace the cowboy lifestyle in Scottsdale.
Channel your inner John Wayne at the aptly named Arizona Cowboy College, a family-owned woâ€¦

entry.title: The chupacabraâ€”how evolution made a mythical monster
entry.summary:
The chupacabra incites fear and fascination, but scientists say the creature is likely a coyote with mange, like the one pictured here. Scientists say a common wildlife disease may be behind the chupacabra legend.
The chupacabra was first reported in Puerto Rico in the mid-1990s. Since then, tales of the mysterious canine-like monster that sucks the blood of livestock have incited fearâ€”and fascinationâ€”across Mexico, the U.S. Southwest, and even China.
But scientists say they can explain the stories with the help of evolutionary theory.
Reports of people spotting the flesh-and-blood chupacabras as recently as 2023 make the mythical creature eminently more accessible for study than, say, the Loch Ness monster or Bigfoot.
In almost all these cases, the monsters have turâ€¦

entry.title: The German eccentric who remade America's forests
entry.summary:
A portrait of Carl Alwin Schenck, the forstmeister whose work at the Biltmore Estate and the Pisgah National Forest, transformed the American landscape. A Gilded Age baron invited Carl Alwin Schenck to manage his forest at the Biltmore Estate. The decision changed America's landscape.
On a spring day in 1945, Christoph Rhoeneck perched at the edge of his familyâ€™s balcony. From the top floor of the brown, wood-clad house, in the middle of the southwest German mountain town of Lindenfels, he watched American tanks rolling up the valley below.Â
Rhoeneck, at the time around five years old, watched the United States Army knock down fences and drive over his neighborsâ€™ gardens, convoying along the villageâ€™s medieval road to the town center.Â
Now 85 years old, he remembers thinkâ€¦

entry.summary: The UN Secretary-General has strongly condemned the killing of civilians, including children, in Israeli airstrikes across Gaza overnight into Wednesday, calling for all parties to uphold their commitments to the fragile ceasefire

entry.summary: Myanmar stands at a crossroads between impunity and humanitarian crisis, as escalating military airstrikes, widespread civilian casualties and mounting evidence of war crimes continue to devastate the country.

entry.summary: Mounting nuclear risks â€“ from Ukraineâ€™s war-torn power plants to Iranâ€™s unresolved safeguards, and renewed inspection efforts in Syria â€“ are testing the global non-proliferation regime like never before, the UNâ€™s nuclear watchdog warned on Wednesday.

entry.title: South Sudan at risk of return to war, UN investigators warn
entry.summary: South Sudan faces a renewed slide into full-scale conflict unless urgent international action is taken, the UN-appointed independent investigative body examining human rights there warned on Wednesday.

entry.summary: What does it mean to build a society where everyone truly belongs? In a world increasingly shaped by digital divides, demographic shifts and climate disruption, the promise of â€˜social development for allâ€™ feels urgent, if elusive.

entry.summary: The UN General Assembly on Wednesday has â€“ for the 33rd consecutive year â€“ adopted a resolution calling for an end to the decades-long United States embargo against Cuba.

entry.summary: Developing countries are receiving less than 10 per cent of the money they need to adapt to a world increasingly vulnerable to extreme weather â€“ putting lives, livelihoods and entire economies at risk, the UN revealed on Wednesday.

entry.title: See the world's cities in a new light with these urban adventures
entry.summary:
This article was produced byÂ National Geographic TravellerÂ (UK).
Why join a standard walking tour when there are plenty of novel ways to experience a city, and plenty of ways to indulge a niche interest? Visitors can get uncover New Yorkâ€™s musical history by diving into its punk scene; learn about the Cold War by driving a Trabant through Berlin; and get a unique perspective of Rio by paragliding above it.
The City of Lights shone brighter than ever last summer with its hosting of the Olympics â€” however, it also has a dark periphery that relatively few tourists seek out. The Petite Ceinture was a railway line with its origins in the mid-19th century. Abandoned since the 1980s, large sections have now been converted into official parks where you can wander among urban foxes andâ€¦

entry.title: At this English nature retreat you can birdwatch from bed
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Thereâ€™s never a bad time to visit Elmley Nature Reserve. In the cooler months, murmurations of starlings cloud crisp winter skies while tens of thousands of waders fill rain-fed pools. The beginnings of spring signal the swooping of lapwings and the boxing of hares, while summer lets loose a burst of butterflies and bees. Autumn is peak season for nocturnal birds, with migratory short-eared owls adding to the roster of barn owls, little owls and their long-eared cousins. And youâ€™ll find all of this perhaps where youâ€™d least expect: the briny marshlands on the southern end of the Isle of Sheppey on the Kent coast. Itâ€™s a clanking industrial heartland, jutting into the North Sea just 40 miles east of London â€” framed by pyâ€¦

entry.title: They mummified a human with ancient tools. It got messy.
entry.summary: The mummy of King Tutankhamun In an excerpt from his new book Dinner with King Tut, Sam Kean explores a weird and wild '90s experiment to replicate ancient mummification techniques. Excerpted fromÂ Dinner with King Tut: How Rogue Archaeologists Are Re-creating the Sights, Sounds, Smells, and Tastes of Lost Civilizations by Sam Kean. Copyright Â© 2025. Available from Little, Brown and Company, an imprint of Hachette Book Group, Inc. Cultures throughout history have mummified their dead, and a handful still do today, but Egyptian mummies remain the most iconic. Unfortunately, the Egyptians wrote down virtually nothing about their embalming process. This leaves experimental archaeology as one of the few avenues available for understanding mummification, and several â€¦

entry.title: In winter, Tasmania channels a surprisingly Nordic vibe
entry.summary:
The best time of year to see the southern lights in Tasmania is from May through September. Like Scandinavia, this remote island has built a culture around remoteness, creativity, slow living, and a deep respect for nature.
They may sit on opposite ends of the planet, one skirting the Arctic Circle, the other floating above Antarctica, but Tasmania and Scandinavia share more than just latitude extremes. In winter, this southern island channels a distinctly Nordic spirit: quiet, creative, and deeply connected to the natural world.
The parallels start with the landscape: glacial lakes, pine forests, wild coastlines. But they run deeper. Like Scandinavia, Tasmania has built a quiet culture around remoteness, creativity, and a deep respect for nature. Winter here isnâ€™t something tâ€¦

entry.title: This is what happens to your brain during menopause
entry.summary:
During menopause, women can experience forgetfulness, brain fog, and other cognitive symptoms. Over the years, studies have found that the end of menstruation comes with brain changes including shrinking brain volume and reduced blood flow. Researchers are delving into structural changes in the brain during the midlife transition.
Soon after she rounded 50, Susan Shaw noticed that things began slipping through her brainâ€”where she parked her car, who she needed to call, even the birthday of her best friend. An avid multitasker at work, suddenly the smallest disruptions threw her off. In the five years since, the problem has worsened.Â
â€œMy brain works differently now than it used to,â€ Shaw says. She compensates by creating elaborate to-do lists and asking coworkers not to interrâ€¦

entry.title: Avocados and monarch butterflies are on a collision course
entry.summary:
After their long journey south, monarch butterflies gather by the millions in a high-elevation fir forest of El Rosario Sanctuary, part of the Monarch Butterfly Biosphere Reserve in MichoacÃ¡n, Mexico. Climate change and illegal deforestation for avocado production are threatening monarch butterfly ecosystems.
The flapping wings of millions of monarch butterflies at theÂ Monarch Butterfly Biosphere ReserveÂ in MichoacÃ¡n, Mexico, create a fluttering sound that Alfonso Alonso describes as â€œmagical.â€Â
The butterflies migrate from the northern United States and southern Canada each year just in time for DÃ­a de los Muertos on November 1 and 2, when celebrations in many parts of Mexico honor deceased ancestors.Â
The serendipitous timing may have led to the belief that a monarâ€¦

entry.title: 10 night sky events to see in November
entry.summary:
A super â€œbeaver moonâ€ rises behind Monte Prena in Italyâ€™s Apennine Mountains in November 2024. This yearâ€™s â€œbeaver moonâ€â€”the largest full moon of 2025â€”kicks off a dazzling month of celestial events, from meteor showers to bright planets lighting up the night sky. The month brings a spectacular lineup of celestial sightsâ€”including a rare chance to see Mercury without a telescope and a "micro" new moon.
November kicks off with Mercury making a brilliant evening appearance, then continues with not one, but three meteor showers. The largest full moon of the year rises early in the month, while a later â€œmicroâ€ new moon offers ideal darkness for harder-to-spot constellations like Orion and Taurus.
Here are 10 celestial events to watch for in Novemberâ€”and when to look up to catch theâ€¦

entry.title: World enters â€˜new eraâ€™ of climate action â€“ but progress must accelerate
entry.summary: While urging countries to accelerate action, UN Climate Change Executive Secretary Simon Stiell struck an optimistic tone on Tuesday following the release of a new report on updated national climate commitments.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Gaza: Humanitarian response scaled up amid faltering ceasefire
entry.summary: Aid teams in Gaza are racing to meet urgent needs with tens of thousands still displaced, sheltering in damaged buildings and makeshift sites, while reports of renewed fighting between Israeli forces and Hamas threaten to derail the ceasefire.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Hurricane Melissa: UN launches sea-lift operation to deliver aid
entry.summary: As Hurricane Melissa makes landfall in Jamaica as a category 5 storm, agencies continue mobilising supplies to support affected communities, with one senior official on the island telling UN News that Government-led preparations have been nothing short of â€œextraordinaryâ€.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Israel responsible for four genocidal acts in Gaza, inquiry chair tells General Assembly
entry.summary: The chair of an independent commission investigating alleged human rights abuses in the Occupied Palestinian Territory, told a General Assembly committee on Tuesday that Israel has committed â€œfour genocidal actsâ€ in Gaza, while leaders had â€œincited the commission of genocide.â€

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: â€˜Horrificâ€™ violence as thousands flee Sudan's El Fasher
entry.summary: After 500 days of siege, the Rapid Support Forces (RSF) militia have reportedly taken control of the key Sudanese city of El-Fasher in Darfur, triggering widespread fear among families, and forcing thousands of civilians to flee.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Russia using â€˜rule of fearâ€™ to silence anti-war dissent, says UN independent human rights expert
entry.summary: Russiaâ€™s abuse of national security and public safety laws to silence opposition to the war in Ukraine has reached â€œalarming levelsâ€, theÂ UN independent expert who monitors human rights in Russia has warned.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: â€˜Catastrophicâ€™ Hurricane Melissa makes landfall in Jamaica
entry.summary: Millions in Jamaica and across the Caribbean are bracing for massive impact from Hurricane Melissa on Tuesday as the UN and partners warn of a â€œsevereâ€ and â€œimmediateâ€ threat.

entry.title: 10 must-see sights in South Africa that most travelers miss
entry.summary:
A group of dolphins creates a network of air bubbles to trap sardines before launching an attack. The African sardine run is when millions of sardines lay their eggs in the cold waters of the Agulhas shoal and then move north along the eastern coast of South Africa. From visiting ancient rock art to sipping wine while on safari, here are the best things to see outside of the most touristed hot spots.
From ancient rock art and epic mountain trails to spicy food scenes and safaris without the crowds, South Africa overflows with sights and activities for tourists. Yet, despite the country being nearly twice the size of Texas, just two destinations dominate touristsâ€™ agenda: the coastal city of Cape Town and the famous Kruger National Park. Theyâ€™re undeniable highlights, but tourists aâ€¦

entry.title: Top 10 things to know about the Day of the Dead
entry.summary:
Day of the Dead, or DÃ­a de los Muertos, is not a Mexican version of Halloween.
Though related, the two annual events differ greatly in traditions and tone. While Halloween embraces terror and mischief on the last night of October, Day of the Dead festivities unfold over the first two days of November in an explosion of color and life-affirming joy.
Sure, the theme is death, but the point of Day of the Dead is to honor the dead by demonstrating love and respect for deceased family members. In towns and cities throughout Mexico, revelers don funky makeup and costumes, hold parades and parties, sing and dance, and make offerings to lost loved ones. What is Day of the Dead?Dia de los Muertos (Day of the Dead) is a celebration of life and death that originated in Mexico. It is noâ€¦

entry.title: Scientists reveal the secret of toads that can turn neon yellow
entry.summary:
As the first monsoon rains in India and southeast Asia begin to swell each year, one type of toad experiences an almost literal glow up. A temporary, hormone-induced wardrobe change transforms male Asian common toads (Duttaphrynus melanostictus) from chocolate pudding brown to lemon yellow in a matter of minutes.Â Â
While the femalesâ€™ skin remains brown, males undergo a color palette makeover to get ready for a lightning round of speed dating. Scientists have long known that the color change coincided with a frenzied, annual two-day breeding event, but they only recently confirmed the specific role it plays.Â
To investigate, researchers from SchÃ¶nbrunn Zoo in Vienna 3D printed toads â€” some brown, some yellow â€” and placed them amid real toads gathering to mate. They found that the â€¦

entry.title: The essential guide to visiting Cairo
entry.summary:
Khan Al-Khalili on Al-Muizz Street is Cairoâ€™s most famous souk (market), and has been trading rugs, lamps, gold, and jewelry for 600 years. The Pyramids of Giza, medieval markets, and the legendary Nile are just a few highlights of Egyptâ€™s energetic capital. Hereâ€™s our guide to where to stay, what to eat, and what to know before you visit Cairo.
Fueled by sugar and caffeine, Cairo is a late-night city, and the energy in both its ancient heart and wealthy â€˜Newâ€™ Cairo is boundless. A city with layers of history; the top drawcards are its most ancient: the Nile River and the Pyramids of Giza, which have towered over this frenetic megalopolis for millennia. And documented stories of Egyptâ€™s empires and eras are on display in a collection of museums spearheaded by the newÂ Grand Egyptianâ€¦

entry.title: What destroyed Napoleonâ€™s army?
entry.summary: Researchers recently found evidence that some of the soldiers who died during Napoleon's retreat from Moscow may have suffered from relapsing fever, caused by the bacteria species Borrelia recurrentis, and paratyphoid fever, caused by a strain of Salmonella. A new genetic analysis of teeth from a mass grave in Lithuania reveals hidden illnesses that plagued the French emperor's soldiers during their disastrous 1812 retreat. As French general and ruler Napoleon Bonaparte returned from a disastrous attempt to conquer Russia in 1812, his army lost tens of thousands of menâ€”many of them conscripted by forceâ€”to a fatal combination of extreme cold, exhaustion, starvation and disease. Based on reports from the time, the main diseases thought to have caused â€¦

entry.title: What makes Appalachian ghost stories so scary?
entry.summary:
TikTok may have led you to believe that Appalachia is populated by an inexhaustible supply of boogers, haints, witches, cryptids. But folklorists say most of the social media videos reveal a fundamental misreading of the region's ghost stories. Very little of the chatter on social media takes up the real lore that makes the region so rich in spooky storytelling.
In the early winter months of 1897, a woman named Mary J. Heaster found herself in regular prayer. Her daughter, Elva Zona Heaster Shue, had just died that January. Only recently married, Zona (as she was known) was a young woman, and her â€œdeath by heart diseaseâ€â€”as the county coroner had determinedâ€”weighed heavily on Mary. Had the coroner gotten the cause of death wrong? Mary prayed that her daughter would return to guide â€¦

entry.title: Why hurricanes are getting more powerfulâ€”more quickly
entry.summary:
As oceans grow warmer, theyâ€™re creating conditions that allow hurricanes to undergo rapid intensificationâ€”when a hurricaneâ€™s wind speed increases by 35 mph or more within 24 hours. Hurricane Melissa is the latest examples of this phenomenon.
Hurricane Melissa grew from a tropical storm to a powerful Category 5â€”90mph and in the span of 48 hoursâ€”and forecasters predict the storm could cause catastrophic flash flooding, life-threatening landslides, and extremely strong winds across the Caribbean.Â Hurricane Melissa is set to make landfall in Jamaica early Tuesday as a Category 5 storm, making it theÂ strongest hurricaneÂ to hit the island since record keeping began in 1851.
These types of explosive jumps have become more common in recent years, with devastating consequences.Â
Befoâ€¦

entry.title: See Brazil's outdoors through its greatest natural wonders
entry.summary:
Otherworldly LenÃ§Ã³is Maranhenses National Park is known for its flooded sands. Brazilian landscapes are known for their drama, with thundering waterfalls, rippling sand dunes and even a Grand Canyon all lying within the countryâ€™s borders.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Home to both the worldâ€™s largest rainforest and mightiest waterfall â€” the Amazon and Iguazu Falls, respectively â€” Brazil is a place of superlatives when it comes to natural wonders, from flooded sand dunes and soaring mountains to archipelagos covered with thick forest.

entry.title: World News in Brief: Funding cuts curb development, human rights in Belarus update, Ebola and mpox in Africa
entry.summary: Sharp declines in global aid are undermining decades of human rights and development progress, the UN Deputy High Commissioner for Human Rights, Nada Al Nashif, warned on Monday.

entry.summary: Millions of people across the Caribbean are bracing for the impact of Hurricane Melissa as it reached Category 5 status on Monday â€“ the most powerful on the scale â€“ defined by sustained winds of at least 157 mph (252 kmh).

entry.title: Children at risk as winter looms amid renewed strikes in Ukraine
entry.summary: Airstrikes and ongoing conflict in Ukraine are leaving civilians â€“ including thousands of children â€“ without homes, power, water and basic services, as humanitarians warn the approaching winter is heightening the risks for communities along the frontlines.

entry.title: Russian army committing murder in Ukraine: Independent rights commission
entry.summary: Drones operated by Russian forces have repeatedly attacked Ukrainian civilians, causing deaths, injuries and large-scale destruction, independentÂ UN human rights investigators said on Monday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Desperate need for water and food continues as Gaza families head north
entry.summary: More than 470,000 movements by civilians heading north inside the Gaza Strip have been recorded since the ceasefire began, said the UN aid coordination office (OCHA) on Monday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Risk of large-scale atrocities in Sudanâ€™s El Fasher grows â€˜by the dayâ€™
entry.summary: Grave atrocities, including summary executions are reportedly being carried out in the Darfuri regional capital of El Fasher by the Rapid Support Forces (RSF) militia, according to the UN human rights office (OHCHR).

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: In Southeast Asia, Guterres presses the case for climate action
entry.summary: Amid deepening global divides and economic uncertainty, the United Nations called for stronger multilateral cooperation and sweeping reforms to global financial and governance systems, emphasising the need for a â€œnetworked, multipolar worldâ€ where equity and inclusion guide decision-making.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Aid cuts shutdown or suspend one in three womenâ€™s anti-violence programmes
entry.summary: Funding cuts are dismantling the frontline organisations working to end violence against women and girls, the UNâ€™s gender equality agency warned on Monday.

entry.title: An inside guide to Ã‰vora, Portugalâ€™s soulful university city
entry.summary:
Ã‰vora, 83 miles east of Lisbon, is a small, medieval-walled city with a grand sense of history. The seat of the Portuguese royal family in the 15thÂ and 16thÂ centuries, its littered with historic sites, from Roman to the remains of palaces. Now, itâ€™s gearing up to step into the spotlight as a European Capital of Culture in 2027, with exhibitions, residencies and performances in the works. But even with this buzz, at heart it remains a low-key, laidback place.
Begin your exploration at the cityâ€™s masterpiece, the Cathedral of Ã‰vora, whose 12th-century towers dominate the skyline. This brooding building is a mix of gothic and romanesque styles, best experienced by climbing to its roof for views across terracotta-topped neighbouring buildings and sunlit plains.
Steps away is the â€¦

entry.title: I've dined in Tuscany for over 20 yearsâ€”this is where to eat in autumn
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Although Tuscany is often associated with balmy summer days and the incessant cacophony of cicadas, itâ€™s in the colder months that its food truly sings. As temperatures drop in October, thereâ€™s a sense of respite after the long, languid months of searing heat. Autumn is a season of hard work, when everything Tuscanyâ€™s fertile lands have to offer is harvested and transformed into produce celebrated the world overâ€”ruby-red wines, thick, acid-green new olive oil, plump porcini mushrooms, and musky white truffles. In the mountains, chestnuts fall and are roasted over open flames, their sweet flesh kissed with smoke. Contrary to the meat-heavy image of Tuscan cooking, vegetables, beans, and pulses are central, earning localsâ€¦
